prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAM04191+1522
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to find the chemical fingerprint of the episodic accretion model in low mass star formation by observing C18O 2-1 (band 6), HCO+4-3, and DCO+5-4 (band 7) with the resolution of 2".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will tune the ALMA Band 6 receiver to observe C18O 2-1 The narrow bandwidth of 117.2 MHz is used to have the velocity resolution of ~0.1 km/s, which is 1/20 of the expected line width (~2 km/s). The rms noise level we want to reach is 10 mJy, resulting in the on-source integration time of 20.7 minutes. With overhead, the total observation time is 55.8 minutes. The requested rms level can provide the S/N ratio greater than 30 within r=5" based on our episodic accretion model. The spatial distribution of the C18O emission is a key discriminator between the episodic accretion and the standard model, so this high S/N level is important.
N2D+ 3-2 and DCO+ 3-2 can be covered simultaneously with our correlator setup. CO and N2H+ are a chemical pair in reactions, and N2D+ can be used instead of N2H+ (if it is detected) to constrain the detail chemistry. With the requested integration, the rms level of this line will be 13 mJy. DCO+ 3-2 is expected to be optically thick at the center of the source according to our episodic accretion model. The self-absorption feature could be used to study the infall velocity structure of the source.
We also want to map the dust continuum of the target to constraint the density and temperature structures of the source, which is the inputs of the chemical calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAM04191+1522
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to find the chemical fingerprint of the episodic accretion model in low mass star formation by observing C18O 2-1 (band 6), HCO+4-3, and DCO+5-4 (band 7) with the resolution of 2".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will tune the ALMA Band 7 receiver to observe DCO+ 5-4 and HCO +4-3 simultaneously to study the D/H ratio. The narrow bandwidth of 58.6 MHz is used to have the velocity resolution of ~0.1 km/s, which is 1/20 of the expected line width (~2 km/s). In order to study the D/H ratio, the rare isotopologues of H13CO+ and D13CO+ would be better at lower transitions, but at Band 6, they cannot be observed simultaneously. In addition, the line intensities are very weak based on our simulation of episodic accretion so that the total observation time (with overhead) will be 4.74 hours to reach the S/N of 10 for both lines. In contrast, DCO+ 4-3 and HCO+ 3-2 are optically thick, so we want to observe higher J-transitions to minimize the optical depth effect. Finally, the requested rms noise level is ~13 mJy to have the S/N of 10 for HCO+ 4-3. The resulting on-source integration time is 19 mins, and the total observation time with overhead is 57 mins.
We will tune one window for H13CO+ 4-3. As mentioned above, H13CO+ 4-3 is expected too weak to be detected for the episodic accretion case. However, the model of standard accretion predicts the peak intensity of ~0.1 Jy. Therefore, 20 mins integration will detect the line at the S/N ratio of 10 if the standard model is operating for this source.
We also want to map the dust continuum of the target to constraint the density and temperature structures of the source, which is the inputs of the chemical calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CB68
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to find the chemical fingerprint of the episodic accretion model in low mass star formation by observing C18O 2-1 (band 6), HCO+4-3, and DCO+5-4 (band 7) with the resolution of 2".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
CB68 and IRAM 04191 are assumed to have similar physical status. Therefore, we use the same setup as for IRAM 04191 as follows.
We will tune the ALMA Band 6 receiver to observe C18O 2-1 The narrow bandwidth of 117.2 MHz is used to have the velocity resolution of ~0.1 km/s, which is 1/20 of the expected line width (~2 km/s). The rms noise level we want to reach is 10 mJy, resulting in the on-source integration time of 20.7 minutes. With overhead, the total observation time is 55.8 minutes. The spatial distribution of the C18O emission is a key discriminator between the episodic accretion and the standard model, so this high S/N level is important.
N2D+ 3-2 and DCO+ 3-2 can be covered simultaneously with our correlator setup. CO and N2H+ are a chemical pair in reactions, and N2D+ can be used instead of N2H+ (if it is detected) to constrain the detail chemistry. With the requested integration, the rms level of this line will be 13 mJy. DCO+ 3-2 is expected to be optically thick at the center of the source according to our episodic accretion model. The self-absorption feature could be used to study the infall velocity structure of the source.
We also want to map the dust continuum of the target to constraint the density and temperature structures of the source, which is the inputs of the chemical calculation.

However, the model of standard accretion predicts the peak intensity of ~0.1 Jy. Therefore, 20 mins integration will detect the line at the S/N ratio of 10 if the standard model is operating for this source.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CB130-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to find the chemical fingerprint of the episodic accretion model in low mass star formation by observing C18O 2-1 (band 6), HCO+4-3, and DCO+5-4 (band 7) with the resolution of 2".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
CB130-1 and IRAM 04191 are assumed to have similar physical status. The only difference is its distance, but our simulation of the ALMA observation with its distance shows difference only in high velocity wings because the infall component near the protostar is more diluted. The peak intensity of the line profile does not change much. Therefore, we use the same setup as for IRAM 04191 as follows.
We will tune the ALMA Band 6 receiver to observe C18O 2-1 The narrow bandwidth of 117.2 MHz is used to have the velocity resolution of ~0.1 km/s, which is 1/20 of the expected line width (~2 km/s). The rms noise level we want to reach is 10 mJy, resulting in the on-source integration time of 20.7 minutes. With overhead, the total observation time is 55.8 minutes. The requested rms level can provide the S/N ratio greater than 30 within r=5" based on our episodic accretion model. The spatial distribution of the C18O emission is a key discriminator between the episodic accretion and the standard model, so this high S/N level is important.
N2D+ 3-2 and DCO+ 3-2 can be covered simultaneously with our correlator setup. CO and N2H+ are a chemical pair in reactions, and N2D+ can be used instead of N2H+ (if it is detected) to constrain the detail chemistry. With the requested integration, the rms level of this line will be 13 mJy. DCO+ 3-2 is expected to be optically thick at the center of the source according to our episodic accretion model. The self-absorption feature could be used to study the infall velocity structure of the source.
We also want to map the dust continuum of the target to constraint the density and temperature structures of the source, which is the inputs of the chemical calculation.

We will tune the ALMA Band 7 receiver to observe DCO+ 5-4 and HCO +4-3 simultaneously to study the D/H ratio. We will tune one window for H13CO+ 4-3. As mentioned above, H13CO+ 4-3 is expected too weak to be detected for the episodic accretion case. However, the model of standard accretion predicts the peak intensity of ~0.1 Jy. Therefore, 20 mins integration will detect the line at the S/N ratio of 10 if the standard model is operating for this source.
We also want to map the dust continuum of the target to constraint the density and temperature structures of the source, which is the inputs of the chemical calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: L673-7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to find the chemical fingerprint of the episodic accretion model in low mass star formation by observing C18O 2-1 (band 6), HCO+4-3, and DCO+5-4 (band 7) with the resolution of 2".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
L673-7 and IRAM 04191 are assumed to have similar physical status. The only difference is its distance, but our simulation of the ALMA observation with its ditance shows difference only in high velocity wing parts because the high velocity component at the central region is not resolved. The peak intensity of the line profile does not change much. Therefore, we use the same setup as for IRAM 04191 as follows.
We will tune the ALMA Band 6 receiver to observe C18O 2-1 The narrow bandwidth of 117.2 MHz is used to have the velocity resolution of ~0.1 km/s, which is 1/20 of the expected line width (~2 km/s). The rms noise level we want to reach is 10 mJy, resulting in the on-source integration time of 20.7 minutes. With overhead, the total observation time is 55.8 minutes. The requested rms level can provide the S/N ratio greater than 30 within r=5" based on our episodic accretion model. The spatial distribution of the C18O emission is a key discriminator between the episodic accretion and the standard model, so this high S/N level is important.
N2D+ 3-2 and DCO+ 3-2 can be covered simultaneously with our correlator setup. CO and N2H+ are a chemical pair in reactions, and N2D+ can be used instead of N2H+ (if it is detected) to constrain the detail chemistry. With the requested integration, the rms level of this line will be 13 mJy. DCO+ 3-2 is expected to be optically thick at the center of the source according to our episodic accretion model. The self-absorption feature could be used to study the infall velocity structure of the source.
We also want to map the dust continuum of the target to constraint the density and temperature structures of the source, which is the inputs of the chemical calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: L673-7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to find the chemical fingerprint of the episodic accretion model in low mass star formation by observing C18O 2-1 (band 6), HCO+4-3, and DCO+5-4 (band 7) with the resolution of 2".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
L673-7 and IRAM 04191 are assumed to have similar physical status. The only difference is its distance, but our simulation of the ALMA observation with its ditance shows difference only in high velocity wing parts because the high velocity component at the central region is not resolved. The peak intensity of the line profile does not change much. Therefore, we use the same setup as for IRAM 04191 as follows.
We will tune the ALMA Band 7 receiver to observe DCO+ 5-4 and HCO +4-3 simultaneously to study the D/H ratio. The narrow bandwidth of 58.6 MHz is used to have the velocity resolution of ~0.1 km/s, which is 1/20 of the expected line width (~2 km/s). In order to study the D/H ratio, the rare isotopologues of H13CO+ and D13CO+ would be better at lower transitions, but at Band 6, they cannot be observed simultaneously. In addition, the line intensities are very weak based on our simulation of episodic accretion so that the total observation time (with overhead) will be 4.74 hours to reach the S/N of 10 for both lines. In contrast, DCO+ 4-3 and HCO+ 3-2 are optically thick, so we want to observe higher J-transitions to minimize the optical depth effect. Finally, the requested rms noise level is ~13 mJy to have the S/N of 10 for HCO+ 4-3. The resulting on-source integration time is 19 mins, and the total observation time with overhead is 57 mins.
We will tune one window for H13CO+ 4-3. As mentioned above, H13CO+ 4-3 is expected too weak to be detected for the episodic accretion case. However, the model of standard accretion predicts the peak intensity of ~0.1 Jy. Therefore, 20 mins integration will detect the line at the S/N ratio of 10 if the standard model is operating for this source.
We also want to map the dust continuum of the target to constraint the density and temperature structures of the source, which is the inputs of the chemical calculation.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to test the episodic accretion model for low mass star formation using the chemical memory engraved in the envelope of low luminosity protostars. For this test, we will observe four low luminosity sources (IRAM04191, CB68, CB130-1, and L673-7), including two VeLLOs (IRAM014191 and L673-7), in C18O 2-1, HCO+ 4-3, and DCO+ 5-4 with the ALMA configuration of C34-1. With these data we will explore structure in chemical abundances between the inner and outer regions of the envelope. Chemical abundances are strongly sensitive to local physical conditions. Thus during a burst the chemical signature will change and this signature will persist even when the system enters the quiescent stage. With knowledge of the physical structure we will be able to extract key information regarding the presence and uncertain timescales of episodic accretion.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy and Space Science, Kyung Hee University

Advanced Astronomy and Space Science Division, Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute
Department of Physics and Astronomy, Seoul National University
